author: bfletcher
title: Scientists Convert Skin Cells Into Placenta-generating Cells
text:
Scientists Convert Skin Cells Into Placenta-generating Cells Fri, 10/16/2015 - 8:46am Get today's life science headlines and news - Sign up now! 
Researchers at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem have converted skin cells into placenta-generating cells. The findings could have implications for regenerative medicine and treatments for women suffering from placental dysfunction. 
There are approximately 100,000 cases every year in the U.S. that account for placental dysfunction diseases. In addition, one in every 100 couples suffers from recurrent miscarriage, according to lead researcher, Yossi Buganim, Ph.D., of the Institute for Medical Research-Israel-Canada. 
Buganim, a professor in the Department of Developmental Biology and Cancer Research at the Hebrew University-Hadassah Medical School, and his team were successful in creating fully functional induced trophoblast stem cells (iTSCs), for the first time. 
Buganim told Bioscience Technology that the team’s approach worked, where other attempts failed, because previous efforts tried to generate trophoblast stem cells from embryonic stem cells, while Buganim used fibroblasts as a starting material. Read More: Scientists Grow Old Brain Cells from Patients’ Skin Cells 
The research, published recently in the journal Cell Stem Cell , was done on mouse cells, but if proved successful in human cells, could result in new options for women. 
“The success of this study, in human cells, is extremely important as it will allow us to take a skin biopsy from patients who suffer from recurrent miscarriage or recurrent placental dysfunction and to generate iTSCs for them,” Buganim told Bioscience Technology . “Then, we can use these patient-derived iTSCs to model their diseases and to investigate the molecular mechanism that underlie the disease.” 
The technology will also provide a platform to run small molecule screens to identify new potential drugs, Buganim said. 
“Lastly, we believe that in the near future we will be able to use these cells for regenerative medicine and to inject them directly into defective embryo to rescue the placental defects.” 
The use of iTSCs is relatively safe, Buganim said, because the cells “know” how to integrate only to the placenta, and therefore do not harm the embryo. Also, “as far as we know these cells are the only induced cells (besides induced pluripotent stem cells) that reach such a high degree of nuclear reprogramming, indicating that their quality is fairly good.” 
There are some downsides however, including that currently they are using viruses to deliver the genes because it is easy. Once the work advances into the clinic the team would need to use mRNA molecules, which are harder to introduce. 
The study was done on mouse cells to show full functionality: injection into early embryo and examination of the developing placenta. But the team still needs to show that the technique is successful for human cells. 
Up next, Buganim hopes, “to show rescue capability in various placental dysfunction mouse models and to generate iTSCs from human cells to be able to start clinical trials.” Topics
